body:
[I posted this issue in Kitty already](https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/issues/7709), but they have simply stated that the bug is that neovim doesn't support the kitty terminal protocol.

**Describe the bug**
The keymapping <C-^> in both vim and neovim switches between alternate files. However, this doesn't work when running vim / neovim inside a kitty terminal. There's a similar issue [here](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/15376) about `<C-enter>`, and there's probably a similar workaround, but I wasn't able to find it so far. Also, [here's an older issue](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/3424) about `<Shift-enter>` in vim that concludes the terminal should be modified / configured to output the right thing.

Something like the following (in `~/.config/kitty/kitty.conf`) should give us a workaround:

```
# Make <C-^> work in vim / neovim
map ctrl+^ send_text all \x1b[30;5u
map ctrl+caret send_text all \x1b[30;5u
```

However, I wasn't able to find the correct thing to map. The workaround in the vim issue linked above says to do `cntrl-v cntrl-^` in (neo)vim to see what it outputs, but it outputs nothing at all. The other issue suggests that maybe [fixterms](http://www.leonerd.org.uk/hacks/fixterms/) needs to be done for kitty.

I ran `kitty --debug-keyboard` and when I press Cntrl-Shift-6 for `<C-^>` it output this:

```
[1,981] Press xkb_keycode: 0x32 clean_sym: Shift_L composed_sym: Shift_L mods: numlock glfw_key: 57441 (LEFT_SHIFT) xkb_key: 65505 (Shift_L)
[1,981] on_key_input: glfw key: 0xe061 native_code: 0xffe1 action: PRESS mods: shift+numlock text: '' state: 0 ignoring as keyboard mode does not support encoding this event
[2,001] Press xkb_keycode: 0x25 clean_sym: Control_L composed_sym: Control_L mods: shift+numlock glfw_key: 57442 (LEFT_CONTROL) xkb_key: 65507 (Control_L)
[2,001] on_key_input: glfw key: 0xe062 native_code: 0xffe3 action: PRESS mods: ctrl+shift+numlock text: '' state: 0 ignoring as keyboard mode does not support encoding this event
[3,131] Press xkb_keycode: 0xf clean_sym: 6 composed_sym: asciicircum mods: ctrl+shift+numlock glfw_key: 54 (6) xkb_key: 54 (6) shifted_key: 94 (^)
[3,131] on_key_input: glfw key: 0x36 native_code: 0x36 action: PRESS mods: ctrl+shift+numlock text: '' state: 0 
KeyPress matched action: sixth_window, handled as shortcut
[3,251] Release xkb_keycode: 0xf clean_sym: 6 mods: ctrl+shift+numlock glfw_key: 54 (6) xkb_key: 54 (6) shifted_key: 94 (^)
[3,251] on_key_input: glfw key: 0x36 native_code: 0x36 action: RELEASE mods: ctrl+shift+numlock text: '' state: 0 ignoring release event for previous press that was handled as shortcut
[3,569] Release xkb_keycode: 0x32 clean_sym: Shift_L mods: ctrl+shift+numlock glfw_key: 57441 (LEFT_SHIFT) xkb_key: 65505 (Shift_L)
[3,569] on_key_input: glfw key: 0xe061 native_code: 0xffe1 action: RELEASE mods: ctrl+numlock text: '' state: 0 ignoring as keyboard mode does not support encoding this event
[3,589] Release xkb_keycode: 0x25 clean_sym: Control_L mods: ctrl+numlock glfw_key: 57442 (LEFT_CONTROL) xkb_key: 65507 (Control_L)
[3,589] on_key_input: glfw key: 0xe062 native_code: 0xffe3 action: RELEASE mods: numlock text: '' state: 0 ignoring as keyboard mode does not support encoding this event
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open file in vim / nvim
2. Open a different file within the editor
3. Press <C-^>

### Expected behavior

It switches back to the first file

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.11.0-dev-242+gba70404c5

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

yes, with Vim 8.2

### Operating system/version

Ubuntu

### Terminal name/version

Kitty 0.35.2

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-kitty

### Installation

appimage

comment_data.body:
kitty maps Ctrl-Shift-6 to switch to the sixth window: https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/conf/#shortcut-kitty.Sixth-window

So you need to unmap it in kitty configuration.

Thank you, that's correct, the fix is to add this to `~/.config/kitty/kitty.conf`:

```
map ctrl+shift+6
```
